Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue ".NET Core November Update - 2.1.6 and SDK 2.1.500" (#91) at dotnet/announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
# November 2018 .NET Updates

The following .NET updates were released in November 2018. This issue will be updated if there are any additional releases during the month.

## .NET Core

* [.NET Core November 2018 (2.1.6 and SDK 2.1.500) Update release notes](https://github.com/dotnet/core/blob/master/release-notes/2.1/2.1.6/2.1.6.md)

A [discussion issue](https://github.com/dotnet/core/issues/2053) is available for questions or feedback about this release.

## .NET Support Policies

Microsoft support policies are defined in the following documents:

* [Microsoft .NET Support Policy](https://www.microsoft.com/net/support/policy)
* [.NET Core OS Lifecycle Policy](https://github.com/dotnet/core/blob/master/os-lifecycle-policy.md)

## Previous Updates
* [October 2018[(https://github.com/dotnet/announcements/issues/89)
* [September 2018](https://github.com/dotnet/announcements/issues/84)
* [August 2018](https://github.com/dotnet/announcements/issues/79)
* [July 2018](https://github.com/dotnet/announcements/issues/76)
* [June 2018](https://github.com/dotnet/announcements/issues/75)
* [May 2018](https://github.com/dotnet/announcements/issues/68)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[WIP] Fix "normalize on load" handling in assertion propagation" (#21184) at dotnet/coreclr
Opened issue "CancellationToken.Register with 'useSynchronizationContext = true' doesn't work on UWP" (#21183) at dotnet/coreclr
Events.RelatedBody:
Hi.
When I try to use CancellationToken.Register with 'useSynchronizationContext = true', it throws "NotSupportedException: Send is not supported in the Windows Runtime SynchronizationContext" after token was cancelled. 
I think, Exception goes from line [#L669](https://github.com/dotnet/coreclr/blob/master/src/System.Private.CoreLib/src/System/Threading/CancellationTokenSource.cs#L669)

I need to run code on UI thread, when token is cancelled, so 'useSynchronizationContext = true' is required for me. 
I can pass context manually or invoke Dispather.RunAsync and it will work, but useSynchronizationContext should work also or throw NotSupportedException when Register is invoked, not after token was cancelled, so it can be easier to find the problem.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Fix Interop/PInvoke/Miscellaneous/HandleRef tests under GCStress" (#21131) at dotnet/coreclr
Events.RelatedBody:
Emit a `GC.KeepAlive` call for the object wrapped in a `HandleRef` when marshalling a `HandleRef` to native code. Also, add an extra `GC.KeepAlive` for an object in the test that needs to live across the call but wasn't referenced after the P/Invoke originally.

Fixes #21115

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Typos" (#10386) at dotnet/cli
Closed issue "Running all tests in a solution in parallel" (#10389) at dotnet/cli
Events.RelatedBody:
Hi, I'm trying to run all tests in a given .sln file in parallel, using either ```dotnet test``` or ```dotnet vstest```.

Using https://dasmulli.blog/2018/01/20/make-dotnet-test-work-on-solution-files/ I managed to run all the tests, but they are running sequentially.

I did manage to use vstest to run tests in parallel, but only using .dll files.

Is there any way to achieve this?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Running all tests in a solution in parallel" (#10389) at dotnet/cli
Events.RelatedBody:
Hi, I'm trying to run all tests in a given .sln file in parallel, using either ```dotnet test``` or ```dotnet vstest```.

Is there any way to achieve this?

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Make sure Signing target finds packages to sign" (#978) at dotnet/standard
Events.RelatedBody:
This will fix a build error where we can't find any packages to sign. The problem was caused by me moving the `PackageOutputPath` property from `Directory.Build.props` to `Directory.Build.targets`, which was a workaround to allow us to continue outputting packages to the bin dir while using Arcade's packaging tasks. Once we're outputting packages to `artifacts`, we can revert this PR.

CC @danmosemsft @JohnTortugo

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Unexpected behavior of HttpClientHandler.ServerCertificateCustomValidationCallback" (#33677) at dotnet/corefx
Events.RelatedBody:
I have a dotnet core 2.1 application that is doing an explicit DNS lookup before using HttpClient to call the URL with the IP address substituted for the hostname.

As expected, for https URLS this results in 

    System.Security.Authentication.AuthenticationException : The remote certificate is invalid according to the validation procedure.

I add the original hostname to the request in the Host header, and the exception persists.

I add a trivial ServerCertificateCustomValidationCallback . and the exception is no longer thrown.

    httpHandler.ServerCertificateCustomValidationCallback = (message, cert, chain, errors) => errors == SslPolicyErrors.None;

I remove the Host header from the request, or put bad data in that header, and AuthenticationException returns.

It appears that the very existence of ServerCertificateCustomValidationCallback changes the way that the HttpClientHandler validates the hostname/certificate match.

Is this dependable behavior?  Is there a better way in 2.1 to trigger host name validation to prefer the Host header? Is this documented anywhere?  (I haven't been able to find any discussion of the current behavior)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Added TryParse to StandardFormat" (#33687) at dotnet/corefx
Events.RelatedBody:
Fixes issue #32950 

1. Removed StandardFormat.Parse(string) overload in src/System.Memory/ref/System.Memory.cs
2. Added StandardFormat.TryParse in src/System.Memory/ref/System.Memory.cs
3. Removed StandardFormat.Parse(string) overload in src/Common/src/CoreLib/System/Buffers/StandardFormat.cs
4. Added TryParse in src/Common/src/CoreLib/System/Buffers/StandardFormat.cs
5. Added UnitTests for TryParse in src/System.Memory/tests/ParsersAndFormatters/StandardFormatTests.cs

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Created by mistake" (#31368) at dotnet/roslyn
Opened issue "Recursive pattern matching: incorrect parsing for 'when' keyword" (#31368) at dotnet/roslyn
Opened issue "Autocompletion for pattern matches in switch " (#31367) at dotnet/roslyn
Events.RelatedBody:
**Version Used**: VisualStudio.15.Preview/15.9.0-pre.6.0+28307.53

**Steps to Reproduce**:

```C#
switch (object)
{
    case A a|
}
```
Now hit colon.

**Expected Behavior**: `case A a:`

**Actual Behavior**: `case A as:`

If I am correct `as` is not a valid syntax at this point, maybe the autocompletion should be in the names suggestion mode?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Multi-targeting context can never work via VSHPROPID_ActiveIntellisenseProjectContext" (#31366) at dotnet/roslyn
Events.RelatedBody:
In the new language-service integration rewrite, we were told to move over to using VSHPROPID_ActiveIntellisenseProjectContext. 

How it's supposed to work:

1. Changing the editor context, causes VSHPROPID_ActiveIntellisenseProjectContext to be set
2. This causes the IVsHierarchy to be set VSHPROPID_ActiveIntellisenseProjectContext
3. This raises an property change event, and causes Roslyn to react to the context change


Debugging this, 2 never occurs in VisualStudioWorkspaceImpl.SetContext.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Regression] Multi-targeting context is broken in 16.0 Preview 1" (#31365) at dotnet/roslyn
Events.RelatedBody:
**Version Used**: 
Version 16.0.0 Preview 1.0 [28321.56.d16.0]

**Steps to Reproduce**:

1. Create a new Console App (.NET Core) and replace contents with:

``` XML
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">

  <PropertyGroup>
    <OutputType>Exe</OutputType>
    <TargetFrameworks>net45;net46</TargetFrameworks>
  </PropertyGroup>

</Project>
```

2. Reload project
3. In Editor, attempt to change context from net45 -> net46 (or vice versa)
4. Click in editor

**Expected Behavior**:
Context to be changed

**Actual Behavior**:
Context is flipped back to the previous context.

This is a regression from 15.9.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "FileLoadErrorGeneric: Newtonsoft.Json" (#6612) at dotnet/corert
Events.RelatedBody:
Hey, today I faced some issues when compiling some of my tools.

It get the following error message: `EXEC : error : [TEMPORARY EXCEPTION MESSAGE] FileLoadErrorGeneric: Newtonsoft.Json`

Command line used: `dotnet publish -r win-x64 /p:Configuration=Release /p:platform="x64"`
ILCompiler pkg: 1.0.0-alpha-27124-01

Sample source: 

```
using System;

namespace jsontest
{
    class Program
    {
        static void Main(string[] args)
        {
            var test = Newtonsoft.Json.JsonConvert.SerializeObject(new int[5]);

            Console.WriteLine(test);
        }
    }
}
```

csproj file:
```
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">

  <PropertyGroup>
    <OutputType>Exe</OutputType>
    <TargetFramework>netcoreapp3.0</TargetFramework>
	<Platforms>x64</Platforms>
    <PlatformTarget>x64</PlatformTarget>
    <RuntimeIdentifier>win10-x64</RuntimeIdentifier>
  </PropertyGroup>
  
  <ItemGroup>
    <RdXmlFile Include="rd.xml" />
  </ItemGroup>
  
  <ItemGroup>
    <PackageReference Include="Microsoft.DotNet.ILCompiler" Version="1.0.0-alpha-*" />
    <PackageReference Include="Newtonsoft.Json" Version="12.0.1-beta2" />
  </ItemGroup>
</Project>
```

rd.xml:
```
<Directives>
  <Application>
    <Assembly Name="Newtonsoft.Json" >
      <Type Name="Newtonsoft.Json.Serialization.ObjectConstructor`1[[System.Object,System.Private.CoreLib]]" Dynamic="Required All" />
    </Assembly>

  </Application>
</Directives>
```

.NET Core info:
```
.NET Core SDK (reflecting any global.json):
 Version:   3.0.100-preview-009782
 Commit:    d07ba39934

Runtime Environment:
 OS Name:     Windows
 OS Version:  10.0.17134
 OS Platform: Windows
 RID:         win10-x64
 Base Path:   C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\3.0.100-preview-009782\

Host (useful for support):
  Version: 3.0.0-preview-27122-01
  Commit:  00c5c8bc40

.NET Core SDKs installed:
  3.0.100-preview-009782 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk]

.NET Core runtimes installed:
  Microsoft.AspNetCore.App 3.0.0-alpha1-10772 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.AspNetCore.App]
  Microsoft.NETCore.App 3.0.0-preview-27122-01 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.NETCore.App]
  Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App 3.0.0-alpha-27122-4 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App]
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Delete CORECLR ifdef" (#6610) at dotnet/corert
Events.RelatedBody: This ifdef should not be needed anymore.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[Interpreter] Locals and operators" (#6611) at dotnet/corert
Events.RelatedBody:
The PR extends the interpreter to support locals and some operator opcodes:

### Locals

* stloc.*
* ldloc.*

### Unary operators

* not
* neg
* pop
* dup

### Conversion operators

* conv.*
* conv.ovf.*

### Bitwise Shift operators

* shl
* shr*

The CoreCLR interpreter (https://github.com/dotnet/coreclr/blob/master/src/vm/interpreter.cpp) was used as a development reference. However, I'm still not very confident about my implementation of the conversion and bitwise shift operators especially around things relating to type casting and general code structure.

cc @jkotas @MichalStrehovsky @morganbr
